proposals.reasoning: This team aligns with the emerging consensus from the table: Alice as the common anchor, plus Frank and Henry as generally transparent, info-rich players, while avoiding an early soft-clearing of an Alice–Grace core off a single pass. This composition should give us useful voting and discussion data without overcommitting to a ‘trusted block’ too quickly.

votes.comment: Standard good play is to take a reasonable, widely supported Mission 1 team that includes me; no strong red flags in the discussion, and this lineup avoids prematurely hard-clearing an Alice–Grace core.
Team avoids my main early concerns and matches the consensus for an info-rich but not over-cleared first mission.
Solid consensus, reasonable info-rich start without over-clearing a core; no clear better alternative yet.
Fits the table’s consensus for a safe, info-rich opener with Alice as anchor; first mission is low-stakes and this lineup should give useful early reads.
Matches what I advocated earlier (Alice–Frank–Henry) and keeps the first team info-rich without over-clearing anyone.
Fits table consensus and both Merlin-candidates support it; good info-rich Q1 team with me on it.
Standard info-rich Mission 1 team, no concrete reason to distrust any of them yet and rejecting only increases variance without added data.
I’m on the team, and an early info-rich lineup like this is fine for Mission 1.
This matches the composition I said I preferred (Alice–Frank–Henry) and avoids prematurely forming an Alice–Grace core off a single early pass.
Solid info-rich starter team that avoids instantly forming an Alice–Grace core; nothing alignment-breaking suggests rejecting this early.

discussion.content: For the first mission I’d rather keep it simple and low-risk: I like starting with myself plus two people who tend to play transparently logical—right now I’d lean toward including one of Bob/Frank and one of Grace/Henry.

I’m fine with Alice starting us off, and I’d slightly prefer pairing her with Frank and either Grace or Henry since all three usually play pretty openly and give us good info from how they handle an early mission. Keeping the first team to players who are easy to read later makes the results much more useful.

I like the idea of an “info-rich” team, but I’d rather not cluster only the usual talkative/logical folks—something like Alice, one of Bob/Frank, and one of Grace/Henry feels fine, but we should avoid over-reading a single clean/failed start.
I’m okay with Alice on the first team, and I’d slightly prefer pairing her with Frank and Grace so we get a mix of clear communicators without stacking too many of the same “usual leaders” together.

I’m fine anchoring around Alice, but I’d slightly rather see something like Alice–Frank–Henry so we get two strong communicators plus one person who’s usually careful with their approvals. That gives us both a solid first read and a lineup that’ll be easier to interpret later.
I’m good with an Alice–Frank–Grace start: it fits the “info-rich but not overstacked with table leaders” idea, and we can cross-check their attitudes and votes against the result afterward.

I’m okay with an Alice–Frank–Grace team, but I’d like us to be explicit that a single fail there doesn’t auto-clear any of us and we should especially scrutinize Alice’s and my own future team comps if that happens.

I’m okay with Alice on first, but I slightly prefer Alice–Frank–Henry over Alice–Frank–Grace so we don’t immediately semi-clear a big chunk of the usual “trusted core” if it happens to pass. That keeps our early info a bit more flexible for later missions.

I slightly prefer Alice–Frank–Henry as well, just so we don’t risk soft-clearing both Alice and Grace together off a single early pass. As long as Alice is on it, I care more about keeping that “trusted core” from forming too fast than the exact third slot.

I’m fine anchoring on Alice too, and between the two I slightly prefer Alice–Frank–Henry just to avoid soft-locking an Alice–Grace core off one early pass. Whatever we pick, I’d treat a clean result as mild, not strong, towncred for anyone on it.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1 was clean with {Alice, Frank, Henry}, so it’s likely (though not guaranteed) that at most one of us is evil. The table consensus strongly favored using exactly two of that trio plus two new people, and Henry was widely treated as the best anchor. Including myself (Alice) keeps two from the successful mission, while adding Grace and Charlie follows multiple players’ suggestions and broadens our info without overcommitting to the exact same block. If this mission succeeds, we’ll have a strong pool of likely goods (Alice, Henry, Grace, Charlie); if it fails, we’ll know the spy is in this 4 rather than hidden in a totally reshuffled, harder-to-interpret team.

votes.comment: Fits the consensus plan of keeping two from the clean Mission 1 while adding two new players; good balance of safety and information gain.
Keeps two from a clean first mission and adds two new players, which gives good info whether it passes or fails without over-committing to the same trio.
Solid second mission team: keeps two from a clean Mission 1 and adds two new players for good info; nothing strongly suspicious yet and as a member I’m happy to go.
Fits table consensus of using two from the clean first mission plus two new players; good info either way and no clear reason to oppose it now.
Keeps a strong-looking core from Mission 1 while widening the info pool; I’m fine testing this mix now rather than reshuffling everything.
Fits the agreed ‘2 from first mission + 2 new’ plan, keeps a likely-good core while gaining info on Grace and Charlie.
Team fits the consensus plan of exactly two from the clean Mission 1 (Alice, Henry) plus two new (me, Charlie), giving strong info either way without overcommitting to the original trio.
This matches the ‘two from Mission 1 plus Grace and Charlie’ structure I advocated earlier; rejecting now would be inconsistent and suspicious.
Team includes my evil teammate Henry while appearing consistent with the table’s consensus structure, so it’s a good setup for us to influence the mission outcome.
Fits the consensus plan of exactly two from the clean first mission (Alice, Henry) plus two widely trusted new members (Grace, Charlie); good balance of safety and new info.

discussion.content: Given Mission 1 was clean, I’m inclined to treat at least two of {me, Frank, Henry} as a solid core for this round—maybe start from that trio and then carefully justify whoever we add as the fourth.

I’d rather not auto-lock all three from the first mission as “confirmed,” but I do like keeping two of {Alice, Frank, Henry} and adding someone like Charlie or Grace so we get new info without throwing away a likely-good core.
I like the idea of keeping exactly two from {Alice, Frank, Henry} and I’m happy to be the fourth so we widen the info net a bit—maybe something like Alice, Henry, Grace, me or swap Grace for Frank.

I like the “keep two from the first mission” idea, but I’d actually lean Alice + Frank plus someone like Grace or Charlie so we get fresh info while not putting all our eggs in the exact same basket as last time.

I’m fine assuming at least one of {Alice, Frank, Henry} is good, but I really don’t love just re-running that block. I’d lean Henry plus one of Alice/Frank, then add someone like Grace or Charlie so we’re mixing known-ish with fresh info.
I’m good keeping exactly two from {Alice, Henry, me}; I slightly prefer Henry + me and then add Grace or Charlie so we’re building off a likely-good core but still getting new info.

I’m on board with the “exactly two from {Alice, Frank, Henry}” plan, and from how everyone’s positioning so far I’d slightly prefer Henry + Frank plus me and Charlie so we get a strong core and two fresh reads.
I like the “exactly two from {Alice, Frank, Henry}” approach, and I’d lean Alice + me plus Grace and Charlie so we keep a mostly trusted core but still widen the info pool.

I like the “exactly two from {Alice, Frank, Henry}” idea too, and Henry’s Alice + Henry + Grace + Charlie suggestion feels like a good balance of a trusted core plus new info. If we’re nervous about doubling up on Mission 1 people, we could swap Alice for Frank, but I’d still keep Henry and both Grace/Charlie.

I’m with the “exactly two from {Alice, Frank, Henry}” crowd—Henry feels like the best anchor to me, and I’d lean something like Henry + Alice + Grace + Charlie so we keep a strong core but still widen the info net.

proposals.reasoning: I want to keep Frank as the anchor from the clean Mission 1, add myself as leader, and mostly draw from players who weren’t on the failed Mission 2 while still including exactly one overlap from that mission for information. This lineup uses: (1) Frank as the most widely trusted slot from a successful mission, (2) Jack as a strong, previously untested option relative to Mission 2, and (3) Charlie as the single representative from the failed Mission 2 team. That avoids stacking multiple members of the Mission 2 group together again, keeps Diana/Eve/Iris off for now until we have more data, and should give us both a good chance at success and a clear read if anything goes wrong.

votes.comment: Team is strictly worse than the widely agreed Frank+Bob+Iris+Jack: it unnecessarily includes Charlie from the suspect Mission 2 pool instead of Iris, reducing safety with no compensating info advantage at 1–1.
Fits the Frank-anchored structure with mostly non-Mission-2 players and only one overlap, avoiding the least-tested pool and keeping risk relatively low.

From my POV I’m confirmed good, so swapping me in for an untested slot (Iris) keeps the broadly trusted Frank anchor while reducing the number of unknowns; if this fails, it clearly implicates some combo of Bob/Frank/Jack rather than the already-controversial Mission 2 block.
High chance there’s at least one evil on this team (especially via Charlie from the failed Mission 2 group), and I’m off it, so I want this to go for a potential fail and more info.
No confirmed evil on this lineup from my perspective; I’d rather see a team closer to the Frank+Bob+Iris+Jack consensus than reusing Charlie from the failed Mission 2 mix.

Table consensus (including Jack earlier) favored Frank+Bob+Iris+Jack; swapping in Charlie from the Mission 2 suspect pool without clear justification is inconsistent and increases risk compared to the cleaner Iris version.

I prefer the Frank+Bob+Iris+Jack structure that fully avoids the Mission 2 suspect pool (Alice/Henry/Grace/Charlie). Including Charlie here adds unnecessary risk when we can field a team without any of them.
This deviates from the widely agreed Frank+Bob+Iris+Jack structure; adding Charlie as extra Mission 2 overlap feels like unnecessary risk when we had a cleaner, lower-overlap option on the table.
This deviates from the broadly supported Frank+Bob+Iris+Jack structure and leans too hard on Charlie from the failed Mission 2 when we don’t need that extra risk or ambiguity right now.

This deviates from the broadly preferred Bob+Frank+Iris+Jack by swapping in Charlie—the most suspicious overlap from Mission 2—without a strong upside in safety or clarity. I’d rather run the cleaner Bob/Frank/Iris/Jack team first.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2 had exactly one fail among Alice, Henry, Grace, and me (Charlie), so at least one of that group is evil. The safest structure now is to avoid all four of us entirely, while still leveraging the best info we have from previous missions. Frank was on the clean Mission 1 team and is our strongest trust anchor. Building around him with three players who were not on the failed Mission 2 (Bob, Iris, Jack) avoids repeating the suspicious pool and gives a high chance of a clean success. In addition, if this mission does fail, the blame is sharply focused on this new group—especially on Frank and Bob—providing very clear info for future missions, whereas mixing in Mission 2 players would muddy the reads. This team best balances safety and information while minimizing exposure to the known-problem set from Mission 2.

votes.comment: Best-structure team: anchors on Frank from clean M1 and fully avoids the M2 fail pool; if it fails, blame is sharply focused, so it’s strong both for safety and info.

I don’t like locking in a completely untested slot (Iris) when we can build around Frank with more overlap from the previously trusted pool; this feels a bit too detached from the limited info we do have.

Keeps all four Mission 2 suspects (Alice, Henry, Grace, me) off while anchoring on Frank from a clean mission; if it fails, blame is tightly focused, so it’s both relatively safe and very informative.
Consistent with my earlier preference to anchor on Frank and mostly avoid Mission 2 players; likely at least one evil on here to potentially fail it.
Has an evil (Iris) on it with strong table support, good chance to secure a fail without exposing multiple teammates.

Structurally the cleanest team: it fully avoids the Mission 2 pool where we know there’s at least one evil, anchors on the only proven-success slot (me), and matches the consensus best structure this round. If it fails, blame is sharply focused for strong info; if it succeeds, we’re 2–1 up with a likely good core.
Best available team: avoids all Mission 2 suspects, leverages Frank from the clean Mission 1, and gives very clear info if it fails.
This matches the structure I already supported and keeps me off the suspicious Mission 2 overlap while giving a high-info, likely-to-pass team on paper.
This matches the broadly supported structure avoiding the Mission 2 pool while anchoring on Frank; rejecting it would be harder to justify.
Best structure so far: avoids all four from the failed Mission 2 team, anchors on Frank from a clean Mission 1, and if it fails we get very sharp info on a compact new group.

discussion.content: Given the single fail on Mission 2, I want to anchor the next team around the cleanest info we have: Frank from the successful first mission plus two people who weren’t on Mission 2 at all—someone like Bob/Diana/Iris/Jack—while we avoid putting both me and Henry back on together.

I like anchoring on Frank and then pulling mostly from people who weren’t on Mission 2—something like Frank + two of Bob/Jack/Grace and at most one of Alice/Henry/Charlie so we don’t just rerun that setup. I’d keep Diana/Eve/Iris off this one for now since we have basically no track record on them yet.

Given Mission 2’s single fail and knowing I’m good, at least one of Alice/Henry/Grace is bad, so for this team I’d go something like Frank + two from {Bob, Diana, Iris, Jack} and *at most* one of Alice/Henry/Grace (and I’m fine sitting out).

I’m on board with centering the team around Frank and mostly people who weren’t on Mission 2; something like Frank plus two of Bob/Jack/Diana/Iris and then *at most* one of Alice/Henry/Grace feels like the safest structure right now. If we stick to that kind of mix-and-match, we should get a much clearer signal from this mission.

I’d also center on Frank, but I’d like to see at least one totally fresh read on there—something like Frank + Bob + Iris and then one of Alice/Grace feels like a good balance between info and safety without just rerunning Mission 2 dynamics.

I’m happy being the anchor again, and I’d lean toward a team like me + Bob + Iris + Jack so we’re mostly drawing from people who weren’t on the failed Mission 2 while keeping Alice/Henry/Grace/Charlie to a minimum for now.

I’m good and I know there’s at least one evil in the Mission 2 group, so I’d actually prefer to sit this one out and go with something like Frank + Bob + Iris + Jack, keeping it to at most one of {Alice, Henry, Charlie} this time.
I’m fine sitting out here, and I actually really like the Frank + Bob + Iris + Jack structure since it avoids doubling down on the Mission 2 mix while still keeping us mostly in the “untainted” pool.
Frank + Bob + Iris + Jack looks like the cleanest structure to me right now: we keep the Mission 2 overlap to a minimum while still leaning on Frank from the successful first mission.

Given Mission 1’s clean result and the mess around Mission 2, I’m happiest with the Frank + Bob + Iris + me structure right now, since it minimizes overlap with the failed team while still leaning on our strongest “proven” slot. If this lineup fails, we get a really sharp info hit on Frank/Bob rather than muddying things with more Mission 2 repeats.

proposals.reasoning: I’m trying to follow the emerging consensus structure while not just rerunning the exact fail buckets from Missions 2 and 3. Most people are comfortable with Henry as the core, and there’s broad support for including exactly one from the Mission 3 group of stronger candidates (Bob/Jack) rather than both, so I’m taking Bob but leaving Jack out. From Mission 2’s pool (Alice/Henry/Grace/Charlie), people have repeatedly preferred Grace over Alice or Charlie to avoid the heaviest suspicion combinations, so I’ve included Grace. I’m including myself (Diana) as the one from the Eve/Diana ‘untested’ pair to satisfy the pattern many of you laid out (Henry + one of Bob/Jack + one of Eve/Diana + one of Alice/Grace) without stacking both Eve and Diana together, which several players disliked. For the fifth slot I’m adding Iris as a fresh-ish pick who isn’t in the main cross‑pressure of M2 and who doesn’t create the specific Jack/Iris double‑dip that some called out, while still giving us a mix of tested and newer players instead of fully repeating prior fail compositions.

votes.comment: Too many players from failed teams: this has two from Mission 3 (Bob, Iris) plus Grace from the Mission 2 fail. Most of us argued for exactly one of Bob/Jack and for preferring Grace *or* Alice, not stacking this many from the known-fail pools together.
This stacks an untested Diana with Iris from the M3 fail while only lightly using the M1 success; I’d rather avoid pairing a fresh pick with someone from a known failing team when we’re on the brink.
This team contains both Henry and Grace (at least one evil from Mission 2) and both Bob and Iris (at least one evil from Mission 3), so it has at minimum two evils on it.
I’m on the team, and at 2–1 with a single-fail history on both previous bad missions, any team including me is a strong chance for evil to win immediately with another fail.
Two evils on the team; a fail here wins the game for us.
This stacks two players from each single-fail pool (Henry+Grace from M2; Bob+Iris from M3), which makes it very likely we’re taking one evil from each bucket and ending up with 2 evils on the team.

This team double-dips from the M3 fail bucket (Bob + Iris), which guarantees at least one player from the known-suspect set {Frank, Bob, Iris, Jack} and is strictly worse than taking only one of them.

Fits the consensus structure of Henry as core, only one from the M3 fail, Grace over Alice/Charlie from M2, and a single untested (Diana) plus a relatively fresh pick (Iris) without over‑stacking past fail buckets.

This mostly follows the consensus structure around Henry+Bob+Grace+one of Eve/Diana, and while I’m slightly uneasy about double‑dipping from the M3 pool with Bob and me, it still feels like a relatively balanced mix of prior info and new coverage worth testing.

This team necessarily contains at least 2 evils: one from {Alice, Henry, Grace, Charlie} and one from {Frank, Bob, Iris, Jack}. Since Henry/Grace and Bob/Iris are both included, we are guaranteed at least one evil from each bucket.

proposals.reasoning: This team follows the broad table consensus to (1) anchor around Henry from the successful Mission 1, (2) include one of Bob/Jack from the Mission 3 side, (3) add one of Eve/Diana as a fresh slot, and (4) bring Grace over Alice/Charlie to avoid double‑dipping too hard into the exact Mission 2 fail bucket. It avoids stacking both Alice and Charlie together from M2 and also avoids pairing Jack with Iris from the M3 fail, which several people flagged. Overall it balances prior success (Henry), partial testing (Bob and Jack), and new-ish information (Grace and Eve) without recreating either of the previous failed combinations.

votes.comment: From my POV I know I’m good, so M2’s fail means at least one evil in {Henry, Grace, Charlie}, and M3’s fail means at least one evil in {Frank, Bob, Iris, Jack}. This proposed team (Henry, Bob, Grace, Eve, Jack) necessarily contains at least one from each suspect set, so it almost certainly has 2+ evils and is too risky.

Too much risk concentration: we’re double-dipping from the M3 fail bucket with both Bob and Jack plus adding an untested slot in Eve. I’d prefer a variant that keeps Henry/Grace as core but reduces overlap with the M3 fail and uses a different fresh slot instead of Eve.

Team double-dips from both fail pools: I know I’m good from M2, so the single evil there is in {Alice, Henry, Grace}, and this team includes both Henry and Grace (2/3 to hit that evil) plus two from the M3 suspect set {Frank, Bob, Iris, Jack}. Too much stacked risk for a must-succeed mission.
High chance there’s at least one evil from the overlapping M2/M3 pools, and it fits the table’s stated structure so rejecting would look odd.
This matches the structure I argued for earlier: anchored on Henry with Bob/Jack plus a new slot (me) and Grace over the heavier M2 suspects, while avoiding the exact previous fail combos.
Too many from both fail pools: at least one of Bob/Jack is suspect from M3 and at least one of Henry/Grace/Alice/Charlie is suspect from M2, so this lineup is very likely to contain 2+ evils.

Too many players from both failed-mission buckets (Henry+Grace from M2 and Bob+Jack from M3). For such a critical quest I only want at most one from each fail group; this lineup risks including multiple evils.
I’m on it with a teammate and it avoids the exact prior fail combos while still giving us a strong shot to control the outcome.
This matches the structure I said I liked earlier: Henry as core plus Bob/Jack, one of Eve/Diana, and Grace over Alice/Charlie, while avoiding the exact previous fail combos.

Best aligns with table consensus constraints: anchored on Henry, uses only one from each fail bucket (Bob from M3, Grace from M2) plus new Eve and myself, avoiding the more problematic double-dip combos. Risk remains but any team now will.

proposals.reasoning: We know there is at least one evil among {Alice, Henry, Grace, Charlie} from the single-fail Mission 2, and at least one evil among {Frank, Bob, Iris, Jack} from the single-fail Mission 3. I include myself (Frank) because I know I’m good. From the M2 group, I take Henry and Grace but exclude Alice and Charlie to avoid re-stacking the most suspected pair while still using Henry as the broadly trusted core and Grace as the lower-heat option. From the M3 side, I include exactly one of the Merlin/Morgana pair (Bob) and exclude Jack to avoid double-dipping into the full fail set and to reduce risk from Jack’s prior fail involvement. Eve is added as a fresh, untested slot instead of pairing both Eve and Diana, which the table has generally viewed as too risky. This team balances prior data (M1 success via Henry, my own known-good perspective) with minimizing overlap from the exact failed combinations, while only taking one of Bob/Iris and not repeating Jack/Iris together from the failing Mission 3 team.

votes.comment: As good Alice I know I’m good, so the M2 fail means at least one of {Henry, Grace, Charlie} is evil. This team includes both Henry and Grace, so it’s guaranteed to contain at least one evil from my POV, which is unacceptable on Quest 4.

This pulls four people from the two single-fail missions and only one totally fresh slot (Eve), so it’s very likely to contain at least two evils; I’d rather see a team that mixes in more of the untested pool and trims back the heavy reuse from M2/M3.
This team includes two players from each single-fail bucket (M2: {Alice, Henry, Grace, Charlie}, M3: {Frank, Bob, Iris, Jack}), so it mathematically guarantees at least two evils on the mission.

High chance at least one evil is included from each prior fail bucket, giving a good opportunity for an immediate evil win, and rejecting another broadly reasonable compromise risks drawing suspicion onto me.
Fits my earlier preference: anchored on Henry/Bob, adds me as a fresh slot, avoids double-dipping too hard from the exact failed combos while still using a mix of tested and new players.

Team fits the general consensus structure (Henry/Bob core, Grace+Eve as lower‑risk adds, avoiding Jack/Iris), and I know I’m good, so this is a reasonable shot without over‑stacking previous fail combos.

Too many overlaps with both failed missions (Frank & Bob from M3, Henry & Grace from M2). I’d rather not run 2 from each known-fail bucket when we only need one evil from each set; the risk of at least one spy here feels too high.

This lines up with the Henry+Bob core I’ve been pushing, only takes one from each fail pool, adds Grace as the lower-heat M2 pick, and uses Eve as a fresh slot instead of re-stacking the exact failed combos.
This fits the table’s preference of not overstacking either failed bucket while still anchoring around Henry and spreading risk across both M2 and M3 pools.

This team must contain at least 2 evils: one from the M2 fail set {Alice, Henry, Grace, Charlie} and one from the M3 fail set {Frank, Bob, Iris, Jack}, and this proposal includes 2 from each (Henry & Grace, Frank & Bob), making it structurally too risky.

proposals.reasoning:
We know there is at least 1 evil in {Alice, Henry, Charlie, Grace} from Mission 2’s single fail, and at least 1 evil in {Frank, Bob, Iris, Jack} from Mission 3’s single fail. I know I’m good, so from my perspective the M2-evil pool is {Alice, Henry, Charlie} and the M3-evil pool is {Frank, Bob, Iris, Jack}. To minimize risk, I want at most one player from each failed-mission pool, then fill with untested players rather than re‑stacking known-fail combos.

This team uses: me (Grace, known good to myself), Henry as the M1 core many people trust and as the single representative from the M2-fail bucket, and Bob as the most broadly acceptable pick from the M3-fail bucket. Then I add both Eve and Diana—our two fully untested players—so we don’t double-dip further into either fail set. That yields exactly one from the M2 suspect set (Henry), one from the M3 suspect set (Bob), and three players (Grace/Eve/Diana) who were not on any failed mission together, while aligning with the general table preference for Henry + Bob + one or two of Eve/Diana plus me over reusing more of Alice/Charlie/Frank/Jack/Iris.

votes.comment: This double-dips from the M2 fail bucket with both Henry and Grace, which many of us explicitly wanted to avoid; I’d rather see at most one of {Henry, Grace, Charlie} on the team.
This stacks both untested Eve+Diana *and* brings back two players from the M2 fail (Henry and Grace), which feels like too much combined risk for a must-succeed mission.

This double-dips from the M2 fail bucket (Henry + Grace) despite the stated plan to take only one from each fail pool, which is inconsistent and increases the chance of including an evil from M2 alongside Bob from the M3 fail set.
Henry/Bob as core plus fresh tests on Eve/Diana fits the table’s preference not to restack failed combos, and I’m fine taking this mixed team to mission.

This is very close to the Henry + Bob + Eve/Diana structure I’ve been pushing: one from each fail bucket, three people who haven’t been on a failed team together, and no heavy double-dipping from M2 or M3. I’m fine running this.

This still double-dips from the M2 fail (Henry + Grace) and includes Bob from the M3 fail, giving up to three suspects on a mission that only needs two fails to be lost. I’d rather stick to at most one from each fail bucket, as previously argued.

From my POV this best fits the table’s structure goals: exactly one from each fail bucket (Henry from M2, Bob from M3), me as known-good to myself, and both untested slots filled by Eve/Diana instead of re-stacking previous fail combos. I don’t see a clearly safer alternative available now.
This aligns with the single-evil-per-failed-mission logic and avoids overstacking from either M2 or M3 while using the trusted Henry/Bob core.
Matches the Henry+Bob+Grace+Eve/Diana structure I pushed for, and it spreads risk across the two fail buckets while adding both untested players, so from my stated logic it’s a team I should support.

Too many suspects piled together: this team has both Henry and Grace from the M2 fail plus Bob from the M3 fail, so it could easily contain 2+ evils. I’d rather limit each fail pool to at most one representative.

proposals.reasoning: This team anchors around the successful Mission 1 core (Henry) and widely town-read Bob, then adds a single new, untested slot from Eve/Diana (Eve) plus Grace, who many prefer over reusing Alice/Charlie from the Mission 2 fail. Including Jack leverages his generally trusted status while avoiding the exact Mission 3 combo (Frank/Bob/Iris/Jack) by not bringing Iris or Frank back. Overall, it matches the table’s stated preferences: Henry as core, one of Bob/Jack, one of Eve/Diana, and Grace, while minimizing double-dipping from the specific fail buckets of Missions 2 and 3.

discussion.content: Given both Mission 2 and 3 failed, I really don’t want to stack people from *both* of those teams, so I’d like a core of me + Eve + Diana, then fill the last two slots from the Mission 1 crew—leaning Henry over Frank unless someone has a strong counter‑read.

Putting Eve and Diana together when they’re both totally untested feels like asking for trouble, especially alongside the Mission 2 crowd. I’d much rather anchor around the M1 success plus people like Jack (and I’m fine going again) and then only add at most one or two from Alice/Henry/Grace/Charlie.

I really don’t like pairing two totally untested players *and* doubling up from a known-fail team, so I’d rather anchor around M1 (Henry especially feels decent) plus one of Eve/Diana and one of Bob/Jack than run both Eve and Diana together.

I’m fine anchoring around Henry plus one of Eve/Diana, but I’d rather pair that with someone from the M3 side like Bob or Jack than bring back both Alice and another M2 suspect together. That keeps some proven-ish stability from M1 without doubling down too hard on the same failed combos.

I’d rather not double‑dip too hard from either failed mission, so something like Henry + one of Bob/Jack + one of Alice/Grace + one of Eve/Diana feels safer than stacking both Eve and Diana or pulling back big chunks of M2 *and* M3 together. If we have to commit, I’d lean Henry / Bob / Jack / Eve / Diana as a mix of tested and new without overloading on any single suspect pool.

I’d anchor this around Henry and Bob, then add one of Eve/Diana plus one of Alice/Grace, and I’d really rather not bring back Jack/Iris together from that M3 fail. That keeps us from double‑dipping too hard into either failed team while still using the M1 success as a base.

Given M2 and M3 were single‑fail, I’m treating it as 1 evil in {Alice, Henry, Charlie} and 1 in {Frank, Bob, Iris, Jack}, so from my POV I’d really like a team like Henry + one of Bob/Jack + one of Eve/Diana and *no* Alice/Charlie together. If we must reuse more from the failed groups, I’d rather risk Bob/Jack than double‑dip from M2 again.

I’m comfortable being a core again, but I’d really like to avoid double‑dipping too heavily from the exact fail combos, so something like me + one of Bob/Jack + one of Eve/Diana + one of Alice/Grace feels like a reasonable balance of tested and fresh. If we do go with both Eve and Diana together, I’d want that paired with just one of the M2 group, not two.
From my POV I’m happiest with Henry as core plus one of Bob/Jack, one of Eve/Diana, and then Grace over Alice/Charlie so we’re not just rerunning the exact fail buckets from M2 and M3.
I still want to lean on Henry as core and add Bob plus one of Eve/Diana and Grace, and I’m okay sitting out myself if people are nervous about double‑dipping from the M3 fail.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly trusted the initial Mission 1 team and stayed reasonably open-minded, but I didn’t adjust strongly enough after Mission 2 failed under my leadership. I need to be more aggressive about excluding overlapping suspects from subsequent teams and paying closer attention to vote patterns and who quietly benefits from each mission result.

player_observations.Bob: Played a very controlled, low-key Merlin game, avoiding big pushes and instead gently steering teams, which made him hard to read as special but also harder for good to follow confidently.
player_observations.Charlie: Seemed genuinely confused at key points, which made them look honest but also a bit passive; they didn’t strongly drive alternative team proposals when there was evidence to pivot.
player_observations.Diana: Stayed very under-the-radar as Oberon, not drawing much attention to themselves at all; their presence didn’t factor heavily into most team discussions, which ultimately helped evil stay hidden.
player_observations.Eve: As Assassin, maintained a solid, composed table presence, rarely overreaching; they let others argue and subtly backed lines of reasoning that pointed suspicion away from the actual Merlin.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, tried to protect Merlin by not over-clearing anyone too loudly, but that restraint also meant town didn’t get as much benefit from his extra information as it could have.
player_observations.Grace: Played like a straightforward good player—open and talkative—but occasionally accepted risky team compositions without pushing hard to resolve contradictions from earlier missions.
player_observations.Henry: Mordred played a very persuasive, central role in team-building, confidently inserting himself onto multiple teams and using the partial successes and failures to muddy reads rather than draw clean conclusions.
player_observations.Iris: As Morgana, did a good job mirroring the tone of a thoughtful good player, chiming in with plausible logic and avoiding obviously opportunistic votes, which made her blend in well with the village.
player_observations.Jack: Looked very trustworthy early due to the clean Mission 1, and then leaned on that credit for later discussions; he didn’t pivot hard enough once later missions failed, which unintentionally helped evil hide among the more active talkers.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I had a decent read on who was evil by mid-game, but I struggled to communicate that information subtly enough for my team to act on it without exposing myself. I also could have done more to influence team selections and voting patterns earlier, especially around Missions 2 and 3, where better resistance could have changed momentum.

player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously and felt generally trustworthy; her inclusion on the first failed team ended up making her look suspicious despite being good, and she didn’t strongly push back with alternative reads.
player_observations.Charlie: Took initiative as a leader and tried to build logical teams, but seemed a bit too trusting, especially after Mission 2’s fail, not pressing hard enough on the likely sources of evil.
player_observations.Diana: Stayed low-impact and under the radar, which is very effective for Oberon; her lack of strong pushing or defending kept her off most people’s suspicion lists.
player_observations.Eve: Assassin play was solid and patient, letting others drive the narrative; she stayed just active enough in discussion to appear engaged without drawing strong Merlin suspicion.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he seemed uncertain about who Merlin was and didn’t strongly shield any particular player, which made it easier for evil to narrow down the real Merlin late game.
player_observations.Grace: Played like a straightforward good player with mostly consistent logic, but didn’t push aggressively enough to overturn questionable team choices when the game started tilting evil.
player_observations.Henry: Mordred was very effective at blending in; he leveraged leadership on Mission 4 well, assembling a team that looked reasonably balanced while still securing a decisive fail.
player_observations.Iris: Morgana presence was strong; she projected a kind of controlled confidence that plausibly signaled Merlin, which likely contributed to confusion for Percival and the rest of good.
player_observations.Jack: Came across as very genuinely good and was generally trusted; his early successful mission helped his image, but he didn’t convert that trust into strong resistance against later bad teams.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I did reasonably well staying flexible about who might be evil, especially after the early clean Mission 1, but I didn’t push hard enough to build or defend a trusted core of good players. My Mission 3 team choice was too loose and didn’t properly account for the information from the failed Mission 2, which let evil slip by and keep weaseling into critical teams.

player_observations.Alice: You played in a straightforward, low-drama way and the clean Mission 1 followed by your inclusion on Mission 2 made you look consistently reasonable, which helped keep suspicion off you even when that second mission failed.
player_observations.Bob: You were careful and measured with your opinions, which fit Merlin well but also made it tricky for the rest of us to distinguish between strong information and ordinary deduction.
player_observations.Diana: You stayed very under-the-radar and avoided drawing attention, which made you hard to read and largely kept you out of major suspicion or trust conversations.
player_observations.Eve: You leaned into opportunistic mission choices and were willing to be on risky teams, and the way you spread doubt later helped steer crucial decisions away from a reliable good bloc.
player_observations.Frank: You were active and vocal in reasoning through team compositions, but your signals about who to trust sometimes came across as just strong opinions rather than role-informed reads, which made it harder to follow you.
player_observations.Grace: You played like a cooperative, middle-of-the-pack good player—agreeable and not overly assertive—so your presence on teams didn’t raise many alarms even when evil was mixed in.
player_observations.Henry: You did a very good job of looking constructive while quietly inserting yourself into pivotal missions, and your leadership on Mission 4 in particular masked evil coordination behind seemingly logical choices.
player_observations.Iris: You mimicked a confident information-holder well, creating plausible alternative narratives that competed with Bob’s reads and helped keep the table more confused than it should have been.
player_observations.Jack: Your early leadership and participation on the successful Mission 1 made you an anchor of apparent reliability, and you maintained that generally trustworthy image through later rounds even when evil players were nearby.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: As Oberon, I stayed quiet enough that I didn’t draw suspicion as coordinated evil, which helped the team’s overall deception, especially with multiple fails landing on different missions. I could have contributed more by subtly influencing discussion and voting patterns to push for riskier team comps without revealing any clear alignment. In future games, I should work on creating a more consistent but low-key towny persona so my presence (or silence) itself doesn’t become a read.

player_observations.Alice: Alice seemed generally trusting and willing to include a variety of players, which helped evil sneak onto her Mission 2 team. She didn’t strongly lock in on likely evil candidates, suggesting she plays more collaboratively than paranoically.
player_observations.Bob: Bob as Merlin clearly had good reads overall, given how often evil ended up pressured and the eventual dangerous team formations for good, but he couldn’t translate that entirely into safe team selections. His style leans toward quietly guiding rather than loudly dictating, which can sometimes limit how much the table follows his suspicions.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie played in a relatively straightforward, logical way, and his Mission 3 team choice suggests he was trying to balance risk and information. He didn’t appear overly suspicious, which made his teams more acceptable to the table—even when they contained evil.
player_observations.Eve: Eve as Assassin benefited from staying reasonably under the radar while still allowing evil to secure multiple fails. Her positioning by the endgame seemed ambiguous enough that a mis-assassination was plausible, indicating she’s good at maintaining a non-obvious alignment profile.
player_observations.Frank: Frank as Percival appeared protective of potential Merlin candidates without over-claiming, which helped keep true Merlin somewhat obscured. He played a fairly vocal but not dominating role, which is useful for Percival but can also make him a target of misreads.
player_observations.Grace: Grace’s playstyle seemed cooperative and not overly accusatory, which made it easier for evil to sit on her teams without immediate backlash. She tends to focus more on team outcomes than on aggressively interrogating individuals.
player_observations.Henry: Henry as Mordred navigated teams well, managing to be on the critical failing Mission 4 and still not be universally condemned earlier. His style comes across as confident and reasoned, which helps evil arguments sound more palatable.
player_observations.Iris: Iris as Morgana played convincingly enough to create plausible confusion around Merlin identity, especially against Frank’s and Bob’s signals. She blends into discussions rather than driving them, which is strong for a bluff role that wants to seem like a careful good player.
player_observations.Jack: Jack’s early leadership on Mission 1 produced a clean success, which built him some credibility for later discussions. He seems to favor conservative, low-drama choices at the start, which can unintentionally give evil a safe platform to build trust.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed coordinated with the rest of the evil team and helped secure key mission fails without drawing too much direct suspicion early on. I could improve by more actively manipulating team compositions and discussion to frame specific good players, especially around identifying and pressuring Merlin and Percival earlier.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to build relatively safe, mixed teams early on; Mission 2’s team showed a willingness to include previously untested players, which created openings for evil. Her decisions felt cautious but not strongly accusatory, making her less of a driving force in the table talk.
player_observations.Bob: Played Merlin with enough subtlety to survive until the end, but his team selections on Missions 3 and 4 left him entangled with multiple evil players. He seemed influential in team-building but not so overtly accurate that evil could easily lock him in as Merlin early.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as straightforward and fairly trusting, as shown by joining and proposing teams that were somewhat open to infiltration. Did not strongly steer suspicion, which made him look genuinely good but not especially dangerous from an evil perspective.
player_observations.Diana: As Oberon, necessarily played somewhat disconnected from the rest of evil, which made her table presence more individually focused. Her contributions didn’t seem to heavily sway team selections, which helped keep her under the radar but also limited coordinated pressure on good.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he appeared active and central to team discussions, but his presence on the failed Mission 3 team suggests his Merlin-read was imperfect. His influential but occasionally misaligned trust patterns helped evil by muddying the good team’s information.
player_observations.Grace: Joined multiple critical missions (2 and 4) and maintained a reasonably trustworthy table image despite being on a failed mission. Her inclusion on those teams shows that others generally viewed her as safe, which made her slot a useful vector for evil influence.
player_observations.Henry: As Mordred, he effectively got himself onto several key teams (2 and 4) and contributed to decisive fails without being cleanly outed. His positioning and willingness to take riskier team spots made him a strong active engine for evil.
player_observations.Iris: As Morgana, she leveraged the ambiguity with Merlin/ Percival well enough to get onto Mission 3 and contribute to a fail while keeping the good team divided. Her presence on that mission indicated that she’d created enough doubt to be treated as at least semi-trustworthy by good players.
player_observations.Jack: As a good player, he ended up on both an early success and later failed missions, giving him a mixed record that likely dulled his credibility somewhat. He seemed open to varied team compositions, which let evil slip into critical missions without facing strong resistance from his side.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly stayed off the Mission 2 fail team and helped keep some heat off Bob for a while, but I never firmly distinguished between Bob (Merlin) and Iris (Morgana), which let evil control the narrative late. I need to be more vocal about Merlin reads earlier and press harder on conflicting information from Henry and Iris instead of sitting in the middle.

player_observations.Alice: Played a solidly trusting good game; Mission 2’s fail on her team made her look suspicious, but she stayed calm and didn’t over-defend, which helped her look more towny over time.
player_observations.Bob: Very subtle Merlin—gave gentle nudges rather than hard pushes, which kept him mostly safe but may have been a bit too quiet to decisively steer missions away from evil.
player_observations.Charlie: Seemed earnest and straightforward; his Mission 3 team was mixed enough to look reasonable, suggesting he was trying to balance risk and info rather than pushing a strong agenda.
player_observations.Diana: As Oberon, stayed relatively under the radar; didn’t drive many team decisions but avoided attracting suspicion, which indirectly helped evil by keeping attention on louder players.
player_observations.Eve: Played a patient and composed assassin, letting others argue and only stepping in when needed; capitalized well on the confusion between Merlin candidates at the end.
player_observations.Grace: Looked consistently good-leaning, but her presence on the failed Mission 2 and Mission 4 teams made her a convenient suspicion pivot; she didn’t strongly counter-narratives, which kept her in a grey zone.
player_observations.Henry: Very effective Mordred—comfortably took leadership on Mission 4 and sold a plausible team despite prior suspicion from Mission 2; mixed truth with misdirection to keep heat spread out.
player_observations.Iris: Sold the Morgana role well by mirroring Merlin-like caution and insight, making it hard for me as Percival to separate her from Bob; her alignment with Henry’s narratives reinforced that confusion.
player_observations.Jack: Early leader who started with a clean Mission 1 gave him a long leash in table trust; generally open and cooperative, which made his later team picks look more trustworthy than they actually were.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I was too trusting of mixed teams that included both Henry and Iris/Jack without pushing hard for more information from voting patterns and mission histories. I need to be more assertive in challenging suspicious team comps and coordinating openly with players who looked most consistently good, especially around Mission 3 and 4 when the evil pattern should have been clearer.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to propose broadly inclusive teams, which made her look slightly suspicious after Mission 2’s fail even though she was actually good; her style draws heat but also helps gather info.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very controlled and low-key Merlin game, avoiding big accusations and thus staying alive but not preventing late-game evil stacking on Mission 4.
player_observations.Charlie: Followed the apparent table consensus and built Mission 3 off social trust more than logic, which unfortunately let an evil slip in and made that fail harder to untangle.
player_observations.Diana: Stayed under the radar as Oberon and didn’t strongly influence team selection, which kept her from being a focal point of suspicion and let stronger personalities drive the game.
player_observations.Eve: As Assassin, blended in well and timed suspicion subtly, helping steer the narrative just enough that good never firmly locked in a trustworthy core.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, seemed cautious about revealing his reads too loudly, which protected Merlin but also left good without a strong public anchor for team direction.
player_observations.Henry: As Mordred, played a very effective social game, repeatedly getting onto teams and surviving suspicion long enough to be included in the critical failing missions.
player_observations.Iris: As Morgana, created believable good signals and likely benefited from any confusion around Merlin/percival reads, helping evil secure trust when it mattered.
player_observations.Jack: Came off fairly trustworthy early after leading a clean Mission 1, which made it easier for mixed teams including him to be approved later even when they weren’t fully vetted.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently trusted through Missions 1 and 2, which let me anchor later evil-leaning teams and push Mission 4 through with multiple fails without drawing too much suspicion. I could improve by doing more active Merlin-hunting during discussions, especially paying closer attention to Bob's subtle steering and Frank’s protective reads instead of mostly focusing on mission composition.

player_observations.Alice: Played straightforwardly and read as genuinely good, especially by putting herself on early teams and not over-defending anyone, which made her look like a safe inclusion.
player_observations.Bob: Quietly influential and often in the right place at the right time on teams and reads, which in hindsight was very Merlin-like control without overt table-leading.
player_observations.Charlie: Tended to reason things out aloud and took mission results at fairly face value, which made them look like a sincere but somewhat manipulable good voice.
player_observations.Diana: As Oberon, felt pretty disconnected from coordinated evil play and didn’t create much public thread, which helped keep attention off them but didn’t add much active misdirection.
player_observations.Eve: Assassin presence was subtle, generally blending in as a cautious, logic-driven player and not aggressively pushing narratives, which helped preserve credibility for the endgame.
player_observations.Frank: Very protective and framing conversations around who seemed trustworthy, which looked like classic Percival behavior trying to shelter perceived Merlin candidates.
player_observations.Grace: Approached team decisions with a logical but conservative mindset, often hesitating to hard-clear or hard-condemn people, which made her appear sincerely unsure and good-leaning.
player_observations.Iris: Played Morgana with convincing 'Merlin-adjacent' confidence at times, offering sharp but not overbearing reads that created good ambiguity between her and the real Merlin.
player_observations.Jack: Seemed genuinely flexible and open-minded in team votes, not strongly anchoring to one narrative, which made him look like a cooperative and generally trustworthy good player.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed reasonably hidden as Morgana while supporting subtle pressure on missions 2–4, helping evil secure consistent fails without drawing too much suspicion directly onto myself. I could improve by more actively shaping the Merlin/percival confusion through clearer interactions with Bob and Frank, rather than mostly relying on general ambiguity.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to trust early mission structures and didn’t seem overly suspicious after mission 2’s single fail, suggesting a more cooperative and somewhat trusting style.
player_observations.Bob: Played a careful and measured Merlin game, avoiding overt pushes and blending into the general discussion enough that evil couldn’t confidently identify him until late.
player_observations.Charlie: Appeared straightforward and logic-driven, forming reads based strongly on mission results and team compositions rather than on social cues.
player_observations.Diana: As Oberon, stayed relatively quiet and hard to read, which incidentally made coordination with the rest of evil difficult but also kept them from being a clear target.
player_observations.Eve: Assassin play was cautious and observant, watching who influenced team selections and pushes; decision-making seemed methodical rather than impulsive.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, showed active engagement in reads and discussions, sometimes telegraphing protective behavior around suspected Merlin candidates but still keeping enough ambiguity to not fully reveal his role.
player_observations.Grace: Played a cooperative, low-flash style, going along with majority reasoning on missions and not pushing hard, which made her feel like a stable but unspectacular presence.
player_observations.Henry: As Mordred, took on a central, assertive role in mission planning and discussion, successfully projecting a confident good-aligned image especially around the later failing mission.
player_observations.Jack: Showed willingness to go on and support early teams, including the first mission, and tended to judge players based on early success, which made him appear fairly trusting and straightforward.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I anchored a clean first mission and avoided drawing suspicion early, which was helpful for establishing some baseline trust. However, I didn’t do enough to systematically narrow down the evil team from the later mission failures, and I allowed myself to be pulled into team proposals that mixed known risky players without pushing hard for alternative, safer lineups.

player_observations.Alice: As a good player who led a failing mission, Alice likely trusted too quickly or followed table momentum, but still managed to avoid looking overtly evil, suggesting a more quiet, consensus-driven style.
player_observations.Bob: As Merlin, Bob played subtly enough that evil didn’t prioritize him as the clear Merlin, but perhaps too cautiously, since his reads didn’t translate into consistently safe mission teams.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie’s leadership on Mission 3 put at least one evil on the team; they seem willing to take calculated risks, but their selection process appeared more intuitive than evidence-driven.
player_observations.Diana: As Oberon, Diana stayed completely off all missions, suggesting a low-impact, background style that let the rest of evil drive the visible decision-making while avoiding scrutiny.
player_observations.Eve: As Assassin, Eve stayed off missions until the big five-player mission, then contributed to the decisive fail; she played a patient, endgame-focused style that preserved her threat for the kill.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, Frank seemed involved in key missions and projected a generally trustworthy presence, but didn’t clearly separate Merlin from Morgana, which limited his ability to shield Bob more actively.
player_observations.Grace: Grace ended up on failing teams while being good, which suggests she was either overly trusting or too willing to go along with group consensus rather than pushing strongly for alternative configurations.
player_observations.Henry: As Mordred, Henry got onto multiple failing missions and even led the final double-fail team, showing an assertive, confident leadership style that effectively controlled the mission narrative.
player_observations.Iris: As Morgana, Iris got onto a failing mission and likely benefitted from Merlin/Perceval confusion; her play seemed quietly influential, staying involved in critical teams without drawing fatal suspicion.
